author: John, Lee
title: Thanks to Physiotherapy department
body: Today I needed to contact the Physiotherapy Department about dates to start my referral physiotherapy treatment. I do not know the staff members name who I dealt with but she could not have been more understanding or helpful and I would just like to say THANK YOU to her for how she spoke to me and the information she gave me - yet another example of excellent NHS staff who are under real pressures from every angle.

title: Excellent & efficent care by all members of staff
body:
I brought my father-in-law to Northwick Park Hospital A&E department on 13/01/2022 following a fall. On arrival there was a small queue at the entrance but upon seeing us a very kind security guard beckoned us inside out of the cold where we could wait until we were assessed by a member of staff. 
The triage process was very quick and the duty Registrar soon outlined a plan of care and we were informed of what that plan of care was. 
We were transferred to HDU and whilst here each and every member of staff (clinical and non-clinical) treated him with kindness, with respect and with care. The also kept us regularly updated. 
Although we did have a wait for the scan, the staff nurse who was overseeing our care, although very busy herself with other patients, took the time to visit our room frequently to check on my father-in-law. His vital signs were recorded regularly. 
Unfortunately, he did require stitches to his head wound and the duty A&E Doctor in attendance that day was both professional and caring.
We spent approx. 8 hrs at Northwick Park Hospital (between the A&E department and the discharge lounge) but we were so grateful for all the care and attention we received on that day. Upon discharge we were given the correct documentation as well as a patient information leaflet on head injury.

readBy.name: London North West University Healthcare NHS Trust
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

title: Quick to arrange an appointment
body:
Appointment within two days.
Positive and explanatory consultation with some plans for progress.
Prescription provided and tests booked.

title: Pleasing experience
body: Visited the audiology department and was treated with respect and empathy.  I would like to thank them for my experience.

readBy.name: London North West University Healthcare NHS Trust

title: Excellent
body:
Went to Barnsley hospital today for a colonoscopy the staff were fantastic each and everyone of them , they were so caring and friendly , I was a bit anxious re: the procedure but they all put my mind at rest and I had the procedure with no problems 
I had a choice which hospital I wanted to have the procedure and Barnsley was my first choice . 
Thankyou to each and everyone of you , your the best wouldn’t want to go anywhere else .

author: Derwent @35
title: Great support from the team
body:
My mother in law and her son lived in the family home together. She had always helped and supported him. Unfortunately she became ill and he didn’t want help for himself or his Mum, At times it was unbearable as he was nasty towards everyone, including his Mum.  
Eventually I managed to speak to a lady from ICATT. Her name was Penny. She was the one person that supported us as a family and didn’t give in. Over time Penny and the team helped him gain confidence and supported him with living a independent life. Without this team and the support from Penny who knows what would of happened. I will always be grateful for the support Penny and the team gave us.

author: eatersh75
title: A fantastic functional team
body: I was in the trauma ward (62) from before Christmas until early January. The nurses and all staff were a delight. Nothing was too much trouble for anyone. What a fantastic functional team they are. They never stop and make every patient feel special. Their dedication is exceptional. I would like to thank everyone involved in ward 62 for their kindness.

readBy.name: Office of John Mason, MSP for Glasgow Shettleston

author: Pedrog33
title: Professional and cheery care
body: I arrived in early January struggling badly with what turned out to a blood clot in my lung. I arrived at the SATA unit where I was looked after by Scott and James who were very professional and caring. I was transferred to ward 5B where the staff continued the professional and cheery care. Please forward my thanks to all.

title: Superb service
body:
I was advised by a Chiropractor that I was attending for treatment away from the medical centre that my blood pressure was very high.
I took readings and went to reception and asked if I could get advice. The receptionist took my information at 10.30 in the morning. At 11.00 I had a call and discussion with the doctor who agreed to increase my medication immediately.
This helped to reduce my concerns and I was extremely impressed by the handling of my enquiry by the receptionist and the doctor.

author: silverwarebd37
title: Cheerful and helpful
body: I have just spent my longest time ever in Hospital and I have to say it was a far more pleasant experience than I thought it would be. All the staff were always very cheerful and helpful, they always had time for even the most demanding of patients. Although Ward 10 is very old now, and visitors are not allowed due to lack of ventilation , I found the week passed pretty quickly. I started off in a very new single en suite room in a newish, wing of the hospital. This was great to begin with and although I really didn't want to transfer to ward 10, within half a day, I was was feeling very relaxed, probably down to all the staff and amiable patients that were present. I think this had a very positive effect on my mental health as being stuck on your own is not for everyone. On the negative side, I would say the food wasn't to my liking, the TV needs a remote, as there was only one channel as far as could work out, and to enter and exit the shower there was a relatively steep (for patients with mobility problems) slope.

author: Missy moody
title: Journey to detox
body:
After a year in ‘training’ with CGL … attending weekly meetings, attending courses and reading lots of quit lit .. I finally understood that for the final push for sobriety I would need support.  
Thankfully CGL were able to support a community detox.  
Words can not fully explain my gratitude at the support I received before during and after.  
Janice the recovery nurse was amazing … super professional but with a mum like warmth. I was guided every step of the way. I will always be grateful for this amazing support and the opportunity to start a new life .

author: CMN78
title: Execellent service from Pharmacy
body:
I was having issues with both the gp practice and my local pharmacy in understanding my young son's medication requirements following a recent diagnosis of Adrenal Insufficiency. This is rare in children and needs very careful management.  
I popped to the pharmacy department at NDDH while my son was attending outpatients, purely on the off chance they might be able to help and advise. Leah, who was working that day, was fantastic, going above and beyond to listen to my concerns and understanding that this is a difficult condition to manage, and that it is crucial to have the correct medication available at all times (separate bottles to be kept at home and school for example). She advised me they could dispense the correct medications from NDDH and was more than happy to help organise this, immediately relieving us of weeks of stress.  
The pharmacy department often get overlooked when the pats on the back are going out to the NHS workforce. The pharmacy staff at NDDH are also working above and beyond in these challenging times and yet were happy to take the time to understand the problems we were facing and able to help us without question.  
We can now collect what we need from NDDH every 4 weeks and know that we no longer have to worry about having to order repeat prescriptions and explaining why our son needs this medication issues twice each month.  
Many thanks NDDH pharmacy!

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust
Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust (2)

author: Robroy75
title: They could not do enough to reassure me
body:
I felt very apprehensive and tense on arrival for an endoscopy procedure even though I had one eleven years ago. From the minute I arrived at the reception to the time I departed the unit after the procedure, every member of the Endoscopy team that I met could not do enough to reassure me prior to the procedure and afterwards. Their care and attitude to me and all the other patients can only be described as excellent and could not have been bettered. One member of the team advised me that their aim is to treat patients like they would like to be treated themselves  
Thank you from a very grateful patient.  
[Unsure about 'Environment']

author: Emmrd63
title: Independent Mental Health Advocacy
body:
I wish I had the advocate from the beginning of my stay in the psychiatric ward.  
It is very difficult to understand the laws and bureaucracy involved in psychiatric treatment and medication. The advocate helped me to understand the 'red tape' involved. It is wonderful to understand that there is someone 'on your side' and will speak for you if necessary. Also to understand the legal side of being sectioned under the Mental Health Act.

author: Sam22
title: My Fathers admission
body:
I called your hospital at approx. 7.45 pm Australia time (around 9.45 am your time)  
I spoke to the nurse unit manager on ward 14, Unfortunately I did not get his name. I was enquiring about my fathers condition.  
I would like to express my sincere gratitude for the professionalism and knowledge that this nurse provided of my fathers condition, I was extremely impressed with the procedures that this nurse advised me that my Father was about to undergo. I believe that this Nurse should be commended on his knowledge and professionalism and that it has been much appreciated. I would be very disappointed if this was not advised to the Nurse on Duty and some kind of recognition awarded; well done.Thank You

author: 4Mumof4
title: Childbirth
body: In October, 2021 I gave birth to my fourth baby. When I left two days later and came home I was dealing with a sort of PTSD from the labour. My community midwife read my notes and said that from reading the notes written by the midwives in the hospital, it sounded like they had attacked me. They didn't ask for my consent to perform checks, to stitch my lower area straight after birth with no anaesthetic, to push down extremely hard with no warning on my stomach to expel blood clots. Medication was not given to me when I should of had it, eg, I had blood clots immediately after birth from haemorrhaging and the midwife informed me that they didn't have time to give me my clexine injections that day, it would be the next day with the next shift of nurses. I wasn't given my omeprazole when I was 2 days on the induction ward, which resulted in my spending my short labour with chest pain from the excess acid and then vomiting all over myself in the bed. I was asked to leave my room the day after giving birth (the previous evening before my baby was feeding correctly) as they needed my bed. They asked me to pack up midway through trying to feed my premature baby and wanted to move me to their staff room. I couldn't use this room, as they had another lady in there with her baby. I was sent home with clexine injection and was not shown how to use them, which resulted in me having a panic attack, due to the fear of using a needle and not treating the blood clots. Hours after I got home from the hospital, I phoned to ask how I administer the injections, only to be told if I couldn't do it, no one would do it for me and I had to just suck it up and get some Dutch courage. The next day, my midwife came and listened to my concerns about the Injections and my sons feeding, resulting in his losing weight. He was sucking on his tongue and not the bottle teat, as he was premature and didn't have his sucking reflex ready for going home. The midwife was very concerned about my mental health and encouraged me to write a complaint. I explained I wanted it to be over and I didn't want to write the complaint. They explained that I could read my notes when I was ready so I could start to process my labour, as that morning I had a breakdown with flashbacks from my labour. Needless to say I never read the notes. My son is now 12 weeks old and the best baby you could imagine. I had always wanted a big family as I came from one myself, but after the treatment I received and the PTSD I have surrounding the labour, I will never have another baby again.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Sylpf39
title: Biopsy procedure
body:
Having been referred to Oral Surgery Department at Royal Cornwall Hospital Truro by my dentist, I attended at the appointed time, was called at the exact time and was welcomed by Omar and Tina, who immediately put me at ease over the procedure that was to follow.  
I was treated with utmost care and consideration during the whole time.  
The procedure was over in a few minutes but I was not hurried by them and was told to take my time when it was all over and I left in good humour, thanks to the care and consideration of Omar and Tina. My thanks are extended to these two nice people

author: earthcw35
title: My visit
body:
I felt very comfortable and at ease  
The doctor was lovely and went through everything with me. Answered all my questions and didn't make me feel uncomfortable one bit.  
Was seen on time.

author: JANE.
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: The counselling service
body:
She helped me to learn to change the way I think about issues I have. I have been practising the things she suggested. I try and slowly am learning how to handle these problems.  
The meditation that we have practised has been very beneficial, however I find it more difficult to use, as my mind wanders. However, Jess has suggested a way around this.  
The sessions I have had with her have been very valuable for me.  
I feel my mental health and my thoughts and my approach to problems have improved.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)
Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: Sunnydisposition
title: Support from CGL with Alcohol problems
body: I was released from prison under licence in 2020 and was referred to CGL by my probation officer. I attended my first appointment and met Sally, my support worker. Sally has supported me for the past six months, during which time I have been able to sort out my life, and essentially my relationship with alcohol. I have attended an 8 week course centred around Recovery. Without Sally’s support and the group sessions, I don’t think I would have come this far. CGL is a truly amazing place, where I feel supported and never judged. Everyone is friendly, positive and professional. I highly recommend this organisation for anyone suffering with drug or alcohol misuse. CGL offers a wide variety of groups, both face to face or online, all of which provide help and advice for anyone looking to improve their life and leave addiction behind.

author: Jeviee12
title: Excellent GP
body: My daughter was unwell with a UTI called 8.30AM GP call back by 9.30AM sample dropped off and antibiotics prescribed by 10am. Amazing service by locum GP and daughter able to return to school by 10.30am

title: Excellent practice
body:
I had a telephone consultation and the Dr asked me to come to surgery. She asked if I minded being seen by a Med Student, which was fine. 
I was very impressed with the student Dr who was extremely thorough, listened to me carefully and asked lots of questions.
He took a very detailed history and also conducted an examination. He explained things as he went along and was very engaged and professional. I felt I had an excellent consultation and felt very confident with his diagnosis.
He is going to make a top notch Doctor in whatever field he chooses because he is relatable,professional,caring and very importantly listens. 👍

title: Going the extra mile
body: My consultant urologist had said he would ask the GP practice to prescribe antibiotics for severe bladder problems I had been experiencing.  The letter from him to the GP had been delayed so I phoned the practice late in the day to explain the problem.  A combination of the surgery receptionist, the pharmacist and the on call GP worked together with me and my consultant's secretary to ensure I was able to obtain the antibiotics just before the surgery closed for the evening.  Knowing how busy they were on this Friday late afternoon, I was so grateful that they were able to deal with my demands so effectively.

title: Great treatment
body: Thank you very much to the very positive, energetic and caring Doctor and team for taking care of my daughter today whilst in AnE. It can be a very upsetting time seeing your child unwell, however, he ensured that we were well informed and his positive persona put a smile on our faces. Singing Frozens well known 'Let it Go' made us smile and feel relaxed. Thank you to the Team.

readBy.name: Royal United Hospital Bath NHS Trust

author: jiveeb67
title: Ipswich Hospital visit
body:
I began to feel unwell one day in December and by 04:00 the next day, my wife had called an ambulance. I was blue lighted to Ipswich. I was found to have Sepsis.  
I cannot fault the care I received in A&E, ICU and Grundisburgh Ward.

readBy.name: East Of England Ambulance Service NHS Trust
East Suffolk and North Essex NHS Foundation Trust

title: Great Practice
body:
The review was conducted via telephone.

The doctor conducting the review demonstrated great experience conducting it with very good interactivity and knowledge.

I can recommend anyone to the Park Medical Centre.

title: I find the staff helpful and the Doctors friendly
body:
Especially right now it would be hard to not find faults with most surgeries with all the Covid related stress for everybody.
I Personally find most staff helpful and am satisfied with the service overall.

title: Great Treatment
body: I cannot praise the staff at this hospital enough. Everyone was very professional,helpful and caring, nothing was too much trouble for them. They were all just wonderful, the surgeon surpassed herself, I had a haematoma appear after a mastectomy, she was on her day off and came in to do the operation for me. She didn’t have to do that, I’m sure she could have got someone else to do it, now this is dedication to your job, I owe this lovely lady big time. I just wish there was some way I could repay all the staff who cared for me , words just don’t seem enough. A very big thankyou to you all .

readBy.name: Barking, Havering and Redbridge University Hospitals NHS Trust

title: Efficient
body: Had a good experience here when visiting the nurse. The reception staff are efficient and the nurse was marvellous.

author: _wazowskiii
title: Disappointed and confused by Dental service
body:
In mid January 2022 I phoned NHS 24 to explain that I had a pain in my tooth/mouth area that was going up towards my eye, and my jaw was locked. I said that it was my very back tooth on my right side at the top. The gum was bulging partly over the tooth that was sore.  
On the next day I was contacted by the dentist (I cannot remember their name unfortunately) from the Royal Alexandra Hospital. They phoned to give me an appointment time where we briefly discussed the issue with the very back tooth.  
I arrived at the hospital, and the dentist looked at the back of my mouth. At this point, I mentioned again how it was the very back tooth and the bulging gum that was giving me bother. I was given two options: root canal treatment or tooth extraction. It was explained that they could only do the part 1 of the root canal treatment and I would need to register myself at a dentist and get part 2 done there. At this point I didn’t think I was registered at a dentist.  
I was skeptical about the root canal as I’ve previously had bother with this tooth/gum area about 3 or 4 years ago which required a course of antibiotics. That coupled with the fact I didn’t think I was registered at a dentist, and I was worried I would not be able to get registered in time to do the part 2, I opted for extraction. The dentist said they would give me an X-ray just to double check everything but when informed that someone else would need to perform the X-ray, they said that it was no longer required and didn't matter. The procedure went fine, and it wasn’t until my mouth was no longer numb that I realised the wrong tooth had been extracted.  
The following day I spent the day in absolute agony and panicking about my missing tooth before my partner insisted we phone NHS 24 again to explain.  
On the subsequent day the hospital phoned to inform me that I was in fact still registered at Bearsden Dental Care, despite not visiting since 2015. I phoned Bearsden dental care and I was given an emergency check up the same day. The dentist could confirm that there is an issue with my wisdom tooth growing in, (the very back tooth that I was describing) and it has caused an infection as well as irritating the gum. I was given two options again, a course of antibiotics to try save the wisdom tooth or wisdom tooth removal. Ideally, I just wanted the wisdom tooth out but considering I now have a huge gap next to it, I didn’t want to jump into removing any more teeth. I’m currently completing the course of antibiotics but it is likely the tooth will need removed regardless.  
Looking back, I should have noticed the red flags with the dentist considering the X-ray issue but at the time I thought they knew best. I’m extremely disappointed and confused that the issue with my wisdom tooth & the infection wasn’t picked up on but I’m extremely glad I followed my instinct quickly as matters could have ended up a lot worse than what they are. Not only do I still have the original issue, but I will now need to look into repairing the issue this dentist has created.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

title: Fantastic treatment
body: My surgery this month could not have been better. All the staff from reception to theatre and consultant were brilliant. I was nervous going in, but their professionalism, calmness and confidence relaxed me immediately. I cannot praise the whole team enough. It made me realise how much we take our health for granted until we need help and support; this team exemplified what health care is about and how much we owe them and other staff like them. Thank you so much

title: Great efficient service
body:
Call answered quickly, gp called back, excellent consultation and prescription issued. 
Now getting much better. Perfect service, thank you.

title: Fantastic practice
body: I have been with this Practice since I was a young child, I moved to University and was then able to rejoin when I returned - many years ago. The Doctor's have helped me during extremely difficult personal times, supported me with numerous health needs, hospital referrals and general care, as a patient. This has always extended to family members who are patients at the practice. The GPs, practice manager and nurses have always been welcoming, extremely supportive, professional and considerate. During unprecedented times, the quality of service has maintained its usual standard - thank you.

title: Taking a long, long time
body: I contacted my GP and they referred me here. I received a letter two months after the referral just to say they are going to give me an appointment soon. It has been another three months and I've not heard anything. I'm giving up hope.

title: Excellent care and attention
body: During a short stay in a&e and eau I felt I was cared for extremely well. Everyone from Drs, Nurses to the domestic staff were polite and caring. Very grateful for the treatment received.

title: Fantastic practice
body: I never struggle to get an appointment, I am becoming more aware how lucky I am to have a surgery like this as most people talk of their struggles to see a doctor. The system is fantastic whereby you are assigned to one doctor and get to see your designated GP, it is rare you don’t see your regular GP, this saves having to repeat things and also it’s nice to have the familiarity. The receptionist are helpful and friendly too. When sitting waiting to be seen it’s lovely hearing the great team dynamic behind the desk. 10/10 for Ingleton Ave!

title: Poor practice
body: My elderly mother in law has tried phoning the surgery to book an appointment to see a doctor , but she is constantly held in a queue.  So she went on bus to try and see someone at surgery to be told see could not be seen that day!! She’s 84 !! . Absolutely terrible surgery when she has gone there on the bus in very cold temperatures to be told she has to return tomorrrow to see the nurse while the  admin staff sit with a cup of coffee and eating biscuits. Absolutely shocking service.

title: No communication
body: Mother in law currently still in Mandarin A  we have no updates we cannot get through on phone have asked to speak to a doctor and not allowed to visit. They won't bring her to the phone she can't use a mobile  she has dementia and must be very agitated about where we are. We needed to speak to a doctor about some urgent tests that she requires which we only found out from appointment letters sent out for later date These test could be done whilst there but she will be discharged and have to go back 2 days later  it just doesn't make any sense. The website says someone will give you a daily update on your loved one this isn't true we are so anxious about what's happening with her. This is someone's mother for goodness sake.

readBy.name: Barking, Havering and Redbridge University Hospitals NHS Trust

title: excellent care
body: Admitted after collapsing at home suddenly. I was informed that I had suffered a heart attack after necessary tests/scans were completed. I underwent an Angioplasty and had two stents put in place. I have nothing but praise for the consultant and his team who carried out the procedure, I was very anxious having only just started to recover from an emergency appendectomy ( ruptured appendix which was carried out by Pinderfields ). The team at Calderdale ensured I was relaxed throughout the procedure and explained everything as it was happening which I found very reassuring. They also appeared to have a very good team spirit and the two main men were quite the double act. My thanks go to them, their excellent team and the  nursing staff on the small side ward where I stayed for a period of four/five days. I would also like to mention the senior cardiac nurse who rang me at home recently to check on my progress and answer any questions I might have . I found him to be very polite, extremely knowledgeable and personable. All in all, a brilliant service from a very competent team of professionals.

title: Caring practice
body: Although things have been difficult over the past two years this practice has given its all to help it’s patients.  Always helpful reception staff and although most contact has been by phone, this seems not to have impacted on the quality of care.

title: Avoid
body: Went to get help and advice with antidepressants and menopause. Was told well the weather doesnt help. I was in tears leaving the practice. Felt not listened to and ignored. Very bad experience. Not the first time. Now I hesitate to contact the surgery because I feel I wont be listened to.

title: Poor Practice
body:
Our mother spent just one month in Pennington Court before her sudden unexpected death.This was before Covid.
Reading through her care notes revealed many issues of concern which were reported to Pennington Court, Leeds City Council and CQC. CQC eventually did inspect this nursing home and downgraded it from Outstanding to Requires Improvement . A safeguarding investigation conducted by Leeds City Council found many areas of concern. The final outcomes meeting was attended by many representatives in health services and social care but , although invited, no representatives of Pennington Court arrived and no apologies were received  .We followed the Westward Care complaints procedure and allowed ample time to investigate our concerns. Throughout the process self imposed deadlines were not met, records were incomplete and it took some considerable time to extract a full set of documents. The details are very sensitive so I don’t feel it is appropriate to share them in full on this platform but for every concern about her care eg very poor quality and often incorrect care notes -Her eyesight was given as very poor in one place and very good in others. She had both glaucoma and macular degeneration . Our concern about this, the least contentious problem, was met with an excuse of ‘ eyesight is used for different purposes’
Despite having an LPA for Health and Well Being ,and visiting every day, we  were not kept informed of changes to medication, or indeed any care issues. I believe there have now been a number of staff changes and these may have been followed by improvements to the care provided. However, unless poor practices are recognised and accepted by management teams then the necessary improvements will not be made.

author: User777
title: MRI Results- NHS Lanarkshire
body:
I was referred for an MRI scan by a neurologist at Hairmyres, NHS Lanarkshire due to suspected MS. I attended the Golden Jubilee hospital for the scan 4 weeks ago and was told the results would be sent to the referring neurologist and then on to my GP. In the past ten days I have called both my GP and the Hairmyres and have been unable to find out the results. The GP does not have the results and at Hairmyres, I have left messages on an answer phone but have had no return call.  
I am feeling anxious about the results and would have hoped by this point that someone would have been in contact with me. The care I have received at appointments for both hospitals has been good but I am worried that these results have gone astray.

readBy.name: Office of Clare Haughey, MSP for Rutherglen

title: Needs severe improvement
body:
This surgery stops and refuses to prescribe you medication you have been prescribed for years. No contact, no discussion. They pine of medical conversations to receptionists to avoid patients which is frankly appalling. No accountability or empathy from doctors. Especially for mental health or neurodevelopmental disorders. Highly concerning they can stop someone’s adhd medication without notice. I wonder if they would do the same to someone with a physical injury. This is discriminatory. 
The surgery staff especially doctors need training on communication skills and empathy. Stop putting awful tasks on receptionists and take accountability for your decisions. 
I really hope one day someone with compassion and good leadership skills runs this surgery. It’s been struggling for a while under it’s current partners. Perhaps they have been in the nhs for so long they’ve forgotten their priority is patient well-being. 
I’ve thankfully moved to another GP after one of pear trees GP’s hung up the phone on me when I asked them why my meds were stopped. I understand speaking to humans might be difficult but if you’re in this profession you might want to atleast try to be good at it. 
Best of luck to the employees of the partners and the patients, they will definitely need it. I hope CQC can see through their fabrication of data and care and finally tell them to change their ways.

title: Appointments
body: We are told never miss your appointments as this costs the NHS Millions. Please practice what you preach. I had a telephone appointment booked for 9am this morning. At 10am I telephoned reception to be told oh don't worry we will let her know you called. Forgive me but it's very easy to ask reception to ring a patient at 9am and give them an excuse. It's simple manners. Yes your going to say like everyone we are very busy covid and etc. Every business in the UK is using that one next week we are told treat it as a cold lol

author: phoenixjb74
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Grateful
body: I would like to thank Mary and all the staff very much so for all your care and kindness. I am a man of few words, but grateful.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: flutedx47
title: Contraception
body: Saw Luke and Kathy. Both were very friendly- made me feel at ease when my blood pressure was high. Very chatty, very friendly, really lovely people!

title: Practice Nurse
body: Saw the Practice Nurse Yesterday for a routine smear. She was gentle, warm, very efficient and professional. I would just like to thank her hence this review.

author: jackpotfc86
title: My Care
body:
I was in for day surgery in April 21. I would like to say how brilliant my care was on the day. I was kept fully appraised of what was happening, staff took time to talk to me and to reassure me around things I was unsure of or nervous.  
I would especially like to mention the care and time taken by SN McQuade, nurse specialist Carole and the brilliant anaesthetist Martin.

author: julyxw39
title: New treatment?
body: I saw a new treatment being trialled (on the bbc news) in the Middlelands called Buvidal, a once a month injection instead of using methadone daily, can I please be considered for this, I've spoken to my key worker at Fareham who said to ask using this feedback form thanks.

author: Frosted35
title: CBT therapy
body:
Iv never had any type of therapy before and wasn't sure what to expect at first, but before you start you have online meetings on what to expect and what they can do for you and how, you also get to ask any questions you might have. This is a group thing that is only a username/number so you don't have to worry about privacy.  
I did 10 weeks of CBT and cant thank them enough its helped me a lot to control my OCD and to also recognise what I need to do and change to keep things going in the right direction. They break it all down and anything you don't understand they will help to clarify. As long as your willing to put the work in to change things in your life and get on the right track don't put it off! Its ok to say I need some help, advice, support and that's what they are there for.

title: Caring staff
body:
Very caring staff whom really do want to help and have the patients best interest in mind. 
Receptionists always make effort to squeeze you in and the GP’s are second to none. Very professional and very reassuring in a difficult time. 
Many thanks to you all.

title: Freindly, helpful service
body: Visit was only for a blood sample but I had a few questions and a request. All were satisfied in a freindly manner, thank you.

author: Dalsi
title: My Fathers care while he was in hospital.
body:
My Dad was in Southwell ward in Nottingham City Hospital. There was no communication from the ward at all. I rang to speak to someone about my Dad's health and care I was told to ring the following day at 10:30 to speak to a doctor. When I rang there was no one available. I was told I couldn't visit. I could speak to my Dad on his mobile but his speech wasn't very good as the days went on.  
After ringing him at the end of November he seemed upset and I couldn't make out what he was trying to tell me. I decided to visit my Dad because no one was answering the ward phone. On arriving at the ward there I was told I couldn't go in as there was an emergency in one of the bays. I said my Dad was in that bay. I was asked the bed number but I didn't know.  
They went off to find out the bed number and I was advised to go into the quiet room. It was a cupboard with folded beds - it was awful. I asked what the problem was but kept being told that they couldn't say. Without anyone saying anything I was more or less being told that my Dad had passed away  
I was so upset. A doctor came in and said my Dad had passed quietly then just went and left me alone until my husband came. My husband asked someone to get the doctor back to answer questions, but they couldn't give us the answers because they weren't my Dad's doctor.  
They took us to see my Dad and he was so cold he couldn't have just passed away.  
I still don't know why my Dad died. If they thought he was so poorly they could have rang me so I could have been with him. They gave me someone else's clothes. It felt like they just wanted me out of the ward. They then went to give me my Dads soiled underwear. It was awful from start to finish.  
They did an autopsy on my Dad but I still don't have the outcome of that.  
I found the way they treated my Dad and myself to be unacceptable.

author: jojomcc
title: A terrible experience!
body:
Attended my GP with suspected kidney stone/infection, gastroenteritis/vomiting/fever/dehydration. I was sent to IRU (Initial Receiving Unit). I was there for all of 10 minutes then in a chair to another waiting area SATA (Specialist Assessment and Treatment Area) . As a frequent hospital visitor this was the first time hearing about or being in SATA. It was very busy with patients coming and going. One member of staff, sometimes no member of staff. ECG, Covid test and bloods done. No issue with heart so little confused.  
Initial consultation with Dr (3 hours in). Will organise xray and collate with blood results and come up with plan. Chest xray done, confused again because no issue with chest or heart. 2 more hours (5 in total) another consultation in the waiting area with doctor. No treatment done at this point.  
My bloods show infection and I need CT scan to rule out obstructing stone. Asked at this point if I could have a painkiller as in lot of pain. Told by nurse at 5:30pm (5.5hrs in) that a porter is on their way to take me for CT. Nurse took me to CT at 8:30pm (3hrs later, 8.5hrs in) to get scan. Back to SATA.  
At this point I had to lie on trolley with pain. Requested another painkiller. Not written up for it so the doctor had to authorise. 3rd consultation with a different Dr at 10:00 pm (10hrs in). They will be admitting me, but just have to wait on bed availability. Saline drip attached around 10:30pm prior to going to ward. Was subsequently unattached at ward as canula not working properly and never attached again.  
A terrible experience! I watched patients cry because they were in pain and asking for updates, told someone would get back to them and never did. I saw patients get angry because felt that they had been abandoned in the room and no-one was updating them. I saw a patient sat it her own urine for hours because no-one would help her, and I watched patients leave because they could not wait any longer to be seen. I did not have that luxury as I needed antibiotics and pain medication.

title: Absolutely amazing
body: Just wanna say how my experience giving birth here was the best.. i got induced and the care i got from the midwifes and paediatric doctors was outstanding! Cant recommended this hospital enough!

readBy.name: Shrewsbury and Telford Hospital NHS Trust

title: caring and kind
body: caring and kind service from the receptionist who answered the phone within 3 minutes all the way through to the Paramedic and GP I saw

title: Excellent treatment given for my knee replacement…
body:
I have been a patient here twice for knee operations, which were the first medical procedures I have experienced. I am in awe of the professionalism, guidance and friendliness shown by all concerned from reception, the pre-assessment team and the consultant surgeon's team. I particularly enjoyed the collaboration with, and encouragement from, my physiotherapist who managed my recovery, using the Home Exercise Program, so successfully that I was able to cycle again in record time!
Many thanks to everyone involved!

title: Great Practice
body: My Husband & I have lived in Buckhurst Hill for 27 years & have been at The Kings Road Surgery all this time. We have always had a great level of service from the friendly & efficient receptionists, the nurses & doctors alike. It's a great comfort to know when something is wrong, big or small, we will be treated with empathy & understanding & this has been the case every time we've needed help. Covid has added enormous pressure to all working at the surgery but you would never know it as they continue to be as professional, courteous & caring as ever. Every member of staff should feel so proud of themselves! You are a formidable team!!

author: skyns69
title: Covid affecting my mental health
body: I have not been able to move properly for years and it all has gotten so much worse lately and with all this covid around my mental health suffered as a result I never had anything like this before

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

title: Excellent timely care
body: After a week of coughing day and night I was becoming more and more exhausted with a tight sore chest, covid tests were negative. Phoned practice at 8, saw Dr at 9, examined and antibiotics prescribed. By the time I drove home by the pharmacy, my Prescription was there and I collected en route. First dose of antibiotics taken at 9.35.  Outstanding care with thanks to the receptionist who booked me in and the Doctor who examined me in the 'hot' room for respiratory infections. Very grateful, thank you.

title: Wonderful Care & Breast Cancer Support
body: The staff & GPs have been wonderfully supportive since I was diagnosed with Breast Cancer in Spring 2021. Despite the pandemic,  GPs have checked in on me &  they & reception staff have responded quickly to my requests for medication, support & questions. The speedy initial check & referral to the Nightingale after my first call to the Practice, despite Covid,  challenges made all the difference. Care is ongoing and I very much value it & are very grateful. Thanks AMP team.

title: Rude staff. Treated as a nuisance
body:
Rude staff. Treated as an inconvenience 
Right hand didn’t seem to know what left hand was doing. Have to check in twice. Why. Then the system hadn’t worked so called again to check in a third time. Not the NHS I know

readBy.name: Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust

title: Fabulous GP Practice
body: I fell off my bike yesterday.  Having woken up with a painful swollen wrist I ‘phoned the Good Practice to find out what I should do.  I had a telephone appointment with a doctor at 09.20 - the outcome of which was that a referral form was left at reception so that I could go to Chelsea and Westminster hospital to get an immediate X-ray to find out if I had broken my wrist.  All wonderfully efficient.  A kind caring practice.

title: Fantastic
body:
As a relatively new patient to this surgery, I would just like to say the doctors and nurses have been brilliant. Always welcoming receptionists and the doctors and nurses are always so polite and understanding. 
Excellent service  - thank you for everything.

author: DenD
title: Well cared for
body:
Well cared for, and explained very well to me what would happen.  
Thank you for your help, much appreciated .

title: So bad
body: This surgery is just unperforming in every way. Most times you cannot even join the queue to talk to someone. When you can join the queue it's often 90 mins or more. The link between the surgery and the chemist is broken and had been for months. Arriving at the surgery you have to queue outside in all weather. Simply shocking.

title: Impossible to access services
body: I needed to obtain a prescription and book an appointment at the GPs request for a routine check. Automated phone system informs you can only request prescriptions on line and so I go to the website which informs that you have to contact the surgery to register for on line services. Ring the surgery, listen to 1 minute 36 seconds of IVR messages and the hear those words " the surgery is very busy, please try later" and it hangs up. Accessing the service is virtually impossible!! And needs a wholesale and systemic review. The GPs / administration need to walk through the processes as a customer to validate the experience and rapidly take steps to improve. It really is shocking

author: piscesxw54
title: A journey of pain.
body:
This is such an emotive reality for me, I'll try to keep to the facts. I've had problems with my hips for years. It's a combination of genetic hip dysplasia and osteoarthritis from a very active life.  
After a number of investigative procedures it was clear I'd worn through the cartilage and the joint was bone on bone. I was advised to have an implant put in and rather than get total hip (due to my age at the time) a BHR (Birmingham hip) was my best option. I had the surgery in Jan 2016. I awoke with a 15 inch incision (it's usually 5" - 7", so twice the size) and told it was a difficult surgery due to the muscle mass in my backside.  
What became apparent was that following my surgery, my pain levels did not improve. Not only that, I lost functionality, I lost movement. I now need to use my hand to lift my left leg into a car and out again - not something I had to do before and not something your average person in their 40's needs to do. Over the years there were a couple of plans to explore why I may still be in pain (via a series of cortisone injections), however these were quickly scrapped and no reasoning given. In my opinion, my surgeon is deficient in communication skills and, dare I say, compassion, let alone any bedside manner. Initially I had appointments yearly, where I would voice that my implant clunked and shifted, that my pain levels were worse than pre-op and that most days walking more than a couple of hundred metres was impossible due to cramping. I would get told (with a smile) that the xray showed the implant was in place and that the surgery was a success. Following this surgery I have not slept normally, I cannot walk more than 100m on a bad day and I take an array of medication daily that includes strong opioids, anti-emetics, migraine meds, among others. The cocktail of drugs I take is constantly evolving. After 4 years of this, I managed to get an appointment with the chronic pain team who, after seeing me, agreed that there was an ongoing issue with the joint, that my problem was not either psycho-somatic nor neurological.  
On the back of this, I was able to get a second opinion. At Glasgow Royal Infirmary they ordered a bone scan and an aspiration of the joint to assess the stresses and possible infection in the joint. Neither investigation came up with answers. There was no infection and no unexpected results from the stress test. I was told there could be a number of reasons for my pain/issues but that many cannot be tested for without direct investigation. I was also told that given my wider history, a revision to a total hip replacement is the best option. It has been over a year since this decision was made.  
To add to my pain issues, I exhibit all of the symptoms of metallosis. Metallosis occurs in up to 5% of metal on metal implants, such as the Birmingham Hip implant I received. The problem is the implant is made of a cobalt and chromium alloy and through both leaching and wear, these metals get into your bloodstream and poison you. I have "morning sickness" (nausea upon waking up everyday -and have had this for about 18mo now), headaches, blurred vision, tinnitus, anxiety, arrhythmia, memory issues. I have highlighted this to both my new surgeon and my GP and highlighted I have not been tested for cobalt or chromium levels in over 2.5 yrs (despite the manufacturers recommendation of 6 monthly testing) as well as the NHS's own policy of maximum yearly testing). I suspect they don't want me to be a metallosis statistic if I'm having a hip revision anyway. So I've had definitive surgery dates set and cancelled on two occasions. One date in Sept and then another in Dec. In the meantime, the metallosis symptoms have worsened, where I am now basically bed ridden (blurred vision, nausea, tinnitus, arrhythmia, tinnitus, and elevated pain) I can no longer work or function. My surgery date has not been reset and no advice available on when it might take place. Nor will anyone undertake a simple blood test to assess the metal ion levels in my blood. I have found my treatment both shockingly bad at times, negligent at best and wholly unacceptable. I've lost over 6 yrs of my life to pain owing to the original surgery and at present there is no end in site for me. Nor do the NHS seem to be taking my care seriously or even following their own protocol on blood ion testing. I just want this nightmare to be over.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

author: jc75
title: Lovely efficient staff
body:
My Mum was admitted to RD&E in the morning for tests and unfortunately due to not knowing if she had Covid (she tested negative) she was sent to Torridge Ward (Infectious ward) until the evening. Thankfully she was in a room on her own during this time.  
We were met by a lovely Nurse (Lyn) who kindly went to the trouble of wearing a mask where my mum could see her mouth as she is deaf and once a room was found we were offered drinks and biscuits. After being told she would have an x-ray around 7:00 pm, at 8:30pm (still no x-ray) she was transferred to Okement Ward.  
By this time my Mum was very tired and anxious, hoping to go home but still waiting for x-ray. As soon as we arrived on Okement ward it had a sense of calmness and everywhere looked spotlessly clean and organised. Immediately a sweet nurse came and took Mum's blood pressure and scanned her wristband, shortly after she came with drinks and biscuits and Navi came and chatted to us. She immediately showed empathy that Mum was tired and anxious and went to contact x-ray to find out what was happening. Luckily she did this because they didn't have mum booked to be collected so a few minutes after this call a nice porter came and collected Mum and within a very short time she was back on the ward again (x-ray department was empty so she went straight in).  
Navi came back and explained everything and told us she had relayed to other staff that we were waiting to see if Mum could go home (we don't live locally) so would appreciate knowing the results as soon as could be expected which is exactly what happened.  
Navi gave us reassurance and showed kindness and compassion (as did Lyn on Torridge). If we had to have left Mum on Okement ward overnight in the care of Navi I can honestly say I would have been less anxious and concerned knowing she were in the care of such a lovely, efficient member of staff. Really makes a huge difference.

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust (2)

title: Great experience yesterday
body: I attended yesterday for my 4th covid injection it was an absolutely brilliant experience it was the best painless injection of them all given by healthcare assistant. So thankful for all the team who have been brilliant throughout the pandemic

title: Surgical procedure
body: Had two moles removed at the dermatology unit at clatterbridge, staff were so lovely and helpful. Very efficient and brilliant service. Thank you.

author: Happy daughter 99
title: Excellent care from the ED and Major Trauma Unit
body:
In early January my 81 year old dad sustained serious chest and back injuries after falling on black ice. He was admitted via The Emergency Department where he was cared by Nurse Shona and Dr. Rona. These two members of staff showed great compassion and their care was excellent. Dr. Rona is certainly a huge asset to the NHS and especially the ED.  
My dad was admitted to the Major Trauma Ward and again I could not fault the care he received by all the nurses, doctors, physiotherapists and OT's. A special mention to his named nurse Joanna who was a complete star keeping me updated regularly on his progress. The Major Trauma Unit is a new unit and again a complete asset to the NHS.  
He is now home and recovering slowly but my family and I cannot thank everyone enough.

author: tangohe34
title: Coil fitting
body: Very professional,  made me feel very comfortable and relaxed. Staff were friendly and knowledgeable,  all question answered, all concerns addressed appropriately.

title: Supportive practice
body: I cannot recommend this surgery more highly. As a patient and also a parent, I feel well supported by this practice. Response times to AskMyGP messages are excellent and consultations are exactly that; a way forward is agreed together with the patient. Given the pressure the surgery must be under, I'm amazed at how good the service is.

author: SEA27
title: Alcohol Dependency
body: I have suffered with alcohol dependency for many years, and it nearly cost me my life over 10 years ago. I lost the use of my entire body, arms, legs, speech, and on admittance to hospital, my family were told if I had not been rushed into hospital, I would have been dead within two weeks. I fought my way back from that and remained abstinent for 6 years. I lost my Dad in 2017, and this did, and still is, crippling me. Unfortunately, I turned to the drink, again, and I would probably be dead had it not been for my Counsellor at Inclusion Visions, Lakeside. All the staff have been amazing but my Counsellor has seemingly gone above and beyond. He has been a rock and it is nice to deal with someone who knows and understands what you are going through. My Counsellor is very professional but, at the same time, you feel so comfortable discussing difficult issues, that you feel as though you are talking to a friend. Suffering from severe anxiety and panic attacks, this has made all the difference to me, and aided in my ongoing recovery.

author: Marwe44
title: Not allowed to deal with my child's appointment
body:
Got a call from oral hygiene about my child, asking to speak to them. I wasn't sure who it was - they confirmed it was the Altnagelvin hospital. I explained to them that they were a teenager and I was their father to which I was told they didn't have to speak me. I replied that I dealt with my child's appointments as I assist them to all appointments and can I not deal with the caller? They disagreed with me. I queried why why they would be looking for a child at 2:30 in the afternoon when they would be in school.  
The caller raised their voice and asked why I being cheeky. I tried to explain that I was the best contact for making an appointment. They asked me to get my child to ring the doctor I asked for a phone number, but the reply was that they should ring the hospital and hung up.  
I felt like I I wasn't allow to deal with my child's affairs and it left me feeling embarrassed . I went to the out patient's to complain and the staff were fantastic.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

title: Lovely, friendly practice
body: I’ve been a patient at this surgery since birth. Always been able to talk to receptionists and see a doctor when needed both for my and my family .

title: Helpful receptionist and GP
body: I phoned Bethesda to make an appointment this morning and the receptionist was helpful, polite and professional. I was very impressed. A GP phoned me within a couple of hours and listened to me, asked the right questions and was very helpful. Overall it was a positive experience and made me feel valued as a patient.

author: silverwaremh84
title: COVID vaccination
body: Nursing staff were excellent . Most professional. I have allergies and they made sure I was safe and well, staying with me to ensure no adverse reactions. Dedicated staff without a doubt.

title: Our NHS is utterly magnificent!
body:
I went to A&E at Wythenshawe today, after a bad fall on some stairs. 
I was dreading it, because the mainstream news was full of reports of 6 and 7-hour waiting times in A&E departments around the UK.
I saw a 'steaming nurse' on arrival who referred me to a nurse-practitioner.  I was then seen within an hour, sent for x-ray and then back to the nurse-practitioner. The whole thing took less than two-and-half hours and everybody was so friendly and professional it made my heart swell to know that our NHS staff are still the best in the world despite the ravages of the Coronavirus pandemic. 
Bravo to all, and whoever came-up with the idea of nurse-practitioners is a bona-fidi genius! 
Wythenshawe Hospital is a 5-star gem, it really is!

title: Superb Service
body: I was concerned about possible prostrate problems and called the surgery to ask to speak to a doctor. I was given a telephone consultation a couple of days later. The doctor was very pleasant and thorough and sent me for blood tests and made another appointment to review the results.  The blood tests were taken soon thereafter and were reviewed with the doctor over the phone as arranged. In that second consultation, further blood tests were arranged that day together with  a face to face appointment with the doctor who examined my prostrate and declared that all was well. I now await the results of the second set of blood tests but don’t anticipate any problem.  All,of this was resolved dealt with very efficiently by all of the staff involved in less than 2 weeks. I’m impressed!

author: Bob1765
title: Brilliant Staff
body:
I attended for an endoscopy examination at Ninewells Hospital Dundee feeling a wee bit anxious.  
I can only describe my treatment there as first class. All staff were brilliant …..they treated me as an individual , not just another patient and plenty of good natured banter and conversation before and after my examination put me completely at ease. I even got a cuppa and a choice of sandwiches.  
Cannot praise them highly enough.

title: A rather splendid experience
body: Had non-urgent sigoidoscopy/hemorrhoid banding carried out via NHS referral from my surgery. Not the most edifying of procedures but the staff were fantastic (and made the whole experience much more dignified than it could have been). Everyone at the hospital from the reception staff to the nurses/health care assistants, consultant and the lovely catering staff (I recommend the chicken salad sarnie and the tea is perfect!) were fantastic. Highly recommended.

author: Nicole_142009
title: Worth her weight in gold.
body: I was admitted to hospital a few weeks ago for the weekend with my asthma. The care I received was amazing from HDU and especially from Kirsten in ward 7C. She is one of the most compassionate, empathetic and dedicated nurses I have met. Nothing was too much hassle for her and she takes the time to chat to all her patients. She’s defo worth her weight in gold.

title: Best of knowledge, care and stamina
body: I was admitted to A and E through 111, with a collapsed lung. waited 8 minutes to be seen. I was then treated in A and E with thoughtfulness and kindness. I waited to 3am to be transferred to a ward,, but was treated and checked on in that time. For a gutted service pared back by an uncaring government, I though staff were doing a top notch job, and please pass on my thanks.

readBy.name: London North West University Healthcare NHS Trust

title: good administration, communication and patient…
body: Our local CAMHS is using this organisation to assist with the high level of demand. Found Psicon to be excellent from the initial contact through to diagnosis. If I ever needed care outside the normal NHS route I wouldnt hesitate to use Psicon

title: Thank you Urology
body: I would like to thank Urology department for how great they were today . Thank you to all the Nurses and the Doctor for making the procedure easier with their friendly and professional approach .

author: Lily High
title: Good care and professional staff
body:
I wanted to express my thanks to all the staff in QEUH who supported me through my assessment, treatment and subsequent discharge today from the QEUH.  
My journey began in SATA unit followed by ARU 5 and finally level 5C.  
A potentially serious condition was assessed, diagnosed and treated by medical, nursing and radiography staff with a high degree of professionalism and compassion . At all times I felt supported, informed and confident I was receiving the best care.  
I was also confident that the environment was safe and clean in the hands of diligent and courteous domestic staff.  
Many Thanks.

title: Great staff
body: The staff are working incredibly hard during an impossibly difficult situation. Thank you all for all your hard work.

title: Amazing Nurse
body: The lovely nurse with the curly hair is wonderful! Always has a smile and a positive attitude. She removed my implant today and I was really nervous but she made me feel extremely comfortable and had a good laugh whilst doing so to take my mind of the procedure. She also done my daughter’s vaccine jabs recently and was brilliant was done quickly to avoid little one having a meltdown. Absolutely lovely woman! She deserves to be recognised for her amazing work.

title: Amazing Nurse
body: The lovely nurse with the curly hair is wonderful! Always has a smile and a positive attitude. She removed my implant today and I was really nervous but she made me feel extremely comfortable and had a good laugh whilst doing so to take my mind of the procedure. She also done my daughter’s vaccine jabs recently and was brilliant was done quickly to avoid little one having a meltdown. Absolutely lovely woman! She deserves to be recognised for her amazing work.

author: pyxisyw69
title: Feeling extremely let down by Rheumatology services
body:
My husband suffers from Ankylosing spondylitis.  
In 2019 my husband had to change to a new medication after one that had worked for 2.5 years began to stop being so effective with pain management . After 4 long difficult months of severe pain between medication, we attended his appointment and he was changed to a new drug. During the appointment they explained the side effects. They highlighted to us how any sever skin reactions needed reported and that it carried a high chance of skin cancer.  
Just 6 weeks into taking the drug he had started to develop small patches of itchy skin. Then he developed a large growth suddenly on his neck. After Christmas 2019 a referral from the GP was made and he was seen in February and had it removed by a private clinic as an NHS referral . After Christmas my husband began to develop an infernal itch in his skin. This began on his arms and legs then quickly spread to every inch of his body, so badly he began to tear lumps out of his skin. He was told to ask the GP but was already on the maximum dose the GP could prescribe without a consultant letter.  
We had called the rheumatology team but they were unable to see him face to face and an appointment was made for a review in March. This didn’t happen due to covid. Having to call an answer machine and wait for a call back 2/3/4 days later. As lockdown ensued and my husband's health became worse and worse and no matter the calls to the team no one gave any suggestions of what to do, despite my constant enquiries about the medication causing a reaction. We were told that the medication couldn’t cause him to be itchy or have bad skin down the phone yet reading the leaflet of the drug said differently.  
He eventually had a phone consult with the doctor in April 2020, where the consultant said to stop the medication. At the time we asked how will he manage the pain and he said ask your GP. When we asked the GP for medication he could only prescribe low grade pain killers as a consultant hadn’t given him a script for anything else. My husband was then seen at the end of August. I requested to go to the appointment as he can no longer manage long appointments without an advocate and support. I was told no due to Covid so I asked him to video call me when the dr arrived so that I could ensure that his point got across that he had been left without proper pain management and that he wanted to be referred to the pain team. The doctor said no he couldn’t call me at the time as he didn’t want to have a conversation like that.  
The doctor spoke with my husband that day about getting a new biological drug started. In August my husband was not in great shape mentally but was able to physically do work from home during the day. Since April his health has continued to go down hill and no one appears to care . He has lost 3 stone in Weight, has had to go on every supplement for blood work as he has become anaemic, with horrific low levels that are still not corrected 4 months later. He has now got muscle wastage on his arms and legs and deep depression because his pain is so unmanageable.  
The doctors do not seem to see that he needs immediate help as they keep pushing his appointments further and further back, although one has rung to ensure that he is coping until his appointment I was devastated when we realised they didn’t even take the time to prescribe him something in addition to help the pain management. The Rheum team provided a script for exactly the same tablets my husband was already taking. When my husband pointed this out they said they would sort it and handed him back the same script in an envelope to give to the GP. This was then recognised to be no different and didn’t have any additional tablets.  
He has now been waiting for an appointment with the rheumatologist nursing team since August 2020. Originally the date was October this became November then had been moved to January 2021. However after receiving a call it’s been now moved until the end of April 2021. I do not see this an an adequate timeframe for someone to wait to begin medication. We would happily have the conversation over zoom to speed the process up or speak to a doctor, or a different nurse or attend a weekend clinic, or attend any day anywhere in Northern Ireland if it would speed up the process.  
My husband now spends on average 16-18 hours each day in bed due to the pain he is in and he can’t move as the pain medication isn’t strong enough. I have to work full time and I have 2 young children and I have to now run around trying to contact doctors and nurses during allocated times ( as a teacher this is a challenge) and then I have to wait for them to call me me back as my husband isn’t able to do this. We have reached the point of total despair. He needs treatment now and needed to be put on treatment in August 2020 not 12 months after stopping the last medication. Overall I am feeling extremely let down by the NHS care.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

title: Poor care
body:
I had my baby in the early hours of 09/01/22 and the care I received was diabolical. The midwives lacked the basic human skills of empathy and sympathy. They failed to provide me with the very basic care. 
I was quickly taken to the labour ward when the midwives realised that I wasn’t suitable for triage. The bed had no bedside rail to provide me with support during my time in labour. I told the midwife I had SPD but she still tried to widen my legs beyond my pain threshold. 
After my baby was born she didn’t tell me the sex of my baby. I was shivering like a leaf to which she responded to by saying that I was in shock. She didn’t offer to cover me up and I had to ask for a sheet. After I was sewed up I was handed my baby to finally have some skin to skin contact. This was nearly 30 minutes after delivery. I was then left to lie in my own blood for two hours where the midwife said she would be back soon. After the paracetamol kicked in I had a shower in a bath which had someone else’s hair inside it. I then asked the midwife if someone would be changing my sheets she said she didn’t have time. I offered to do it myself to which prompted her to reluctantly changed my sheets. 

I was then moved to a ward so my baby could be monitored for 12 hours. My observations were done 4 hours after being moved to the ward. This was only because I felt like I had a temperature. 

I work for the NHS and I have done so for 7 years. I have never failed to give my patients the very basic care. I have always given my patients the care and treatment I would want for myself and my loved ones. I mean, that is what they teach you. And there are some things that can’t be taught. I was so ashamed and disappointed that I was in the receiving end of such poor care. I am so grateful that my labour was short, I dread to imagine how it would have been if it was longer. 

If I had to rate the care and treatment of this department, it would be a 1/10. That’s me being generous. Queens hospital you need to retrain your staff, give your staff regular supervision, look out for signs of burn out and take a leaf out of Royal London Hospital.

readBy.name: Barking, Havering and Redbridge University Hospitals NHS Trust

title: My first appointment
body: I changed drs as could not get appointments let alone get through to them on the phone. So glad I did as I had a phone consultation with the dr first who then gave me an appointment within a couple of days. I was seen by a paramedic who has had alot of experience.  He was so polite and easy to talk to and also put my mind at ease and new what he was talking about.

title: Speedy,professional caring service
body: I had the first one done in July 2021 in Stockton.I received an appointment within 3 weeks of being referred instead of over a year with the NHS hospital service. Excellent service all round, I am very claustrophobic and was concerned re having my face covered but everyone was very patient and someone held my hand throughout. The second one was done this week in Gateshead, again no complaints at all and the same surgeon! Another hand holder helped enormously. I have told everyone about this amazing facility.

title: Great practice
body:
I have recently moved up to Whickham to live and found out that it would be beneficial to change my surgery from central Gateshead to the Whickham surgery which I can walk to.
I have found since I have registered the doctors and supporting staff have been excellent and always helpful and caring. 
I have been in to see the doctors on many occasions with no trouble getting an appointment even during the pandemic.
Service is 10 out of 10
Best thing I have done change practices.

title: Beyond terrible
body:
Impossible to get an appointment. Can call several hundreds times between 08:00 and 08:30, only to be told (once you finally get through) that they are fully booked and to try again tomorrow.

Recently found they have an online tool for submitting a consultation-request form, but that always seems to be unavailable; saying to try again the following morning. 
Having worked a great deal in I.T., this is the only such system I've ever encountered which isn't available 24/7 - It's ridiculous.  

How is anyone who works full-time supposed to get an appointment? 

Leaving this surgery ASAP.

title: Terrible
body: Terrible service. If I could give no stars I would. For starters the mental health team are terrible. Had to discuss things that happened in my childhood and they showed no compassion at all. Just ticked a few boxes and was told to go home. It was the middle of the night and I had no way of getting home, but they refused to help me (which was their duty of care). Was stranded until morning and was told it wasn't their problem. When asking for help staff were rude and dismissive. Wouldn't trust them to care for a goldfish.

readBy.name: University Hospitals of Derby and Burton NHS Foundation Trust

title: Poor service
body:
I have tried to ring 3 times to book a blood test which I was asked to do.
1st time the phone ran for over 5 minutes with no one answering
2nd time I got engaged
3rd time the whole surgery is on training so wont answer unless an emergency.
When is a good time to ring ? is the expectation to hang on for longer ?
